p: Thymus (Lamiaceae) comprises over 300 species of hardy perennial herbaceous plants and subshrubs, which are native to southern Europe, Asia and North Africa (Tepe et al. 2004). Thyme is a distinguished condiment that is used in traditional medicine for several purposes, for example, as an anti-inflammatory and analgesic agent (Alamger et al. 2015; Amirghofran et al. 2016). The pharmacological activity of Thymus capitatus Hoff. et Link. EO have been demonstrated, including antiseptic, antioxidant, and antimicrobial properties (Consentino et al. 1999; Al-Mustafa & Al-Thunibat 2008; Mkaddem et al. 2010; Russo et al. 2013; Džamić et al. 2015), however, the antinociceptive and analgesic properties have not yet been evaluated. Therefore, the present study was designed to determine the major constituents from the T. capitatus EO and to evaluate its antinociceptive effects by in vivo and in vitro procedures.
